instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.CD3217: What is CD3217? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook won’t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.820-01949: What is 820-01949? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.820-01700: What is 820-01700? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.820-02020: What is 820-02020? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook won’t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01949</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with bad <CHIP>CD3217</CHIP>
threads.message:
Hello, 

A <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01949</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> came in with one port not working at all and all three giving 5V.. 
I marked the bad <CHIP>CD3217</CHIP> and it was <SIGNAL>U3100_T</SIGNAL>.
I was able to verify it was bad by measuring <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4_XT_USBC</SIGNAL>; it was 0.045 (diode mode) shorted to ground.. where it should be 0.200+

My question is; I don't have a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01949</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> to take the <CHIP>CD3217</CHIP> out of.. cause I read online <CHIP>CD3217</CHIP> now are programmed and need to be taken off of an exact donor; is this true? The board I have with <CHIP>CD3217</CHIP> is <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01949</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with bad <CHIP>CD3217</CHIP>
threads.message: I went ahead and took of a CD3217B12 from 01700 and swapped it with the bad <CHIP>U3100</CHIP>-T (CD3217B12) on 01949; both ports on the left side now cycles whilst at 5V..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01949</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with bad <CHIP>CD3217</CHIP>
threads.message: I remembered I have <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02020</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01949</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with bad <CHIP>CD3217</CHIP>
threads.message: That cycle is apparently caused by the DC-in flex board.. now I'm stuck and I believe a need a CD3217B12 from the same model

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01949</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with bad <CHIP>CD3217</CHIP>
threads.message:
Peoples claim on Internet to have problems soldering <CHIP>CD3217</CHIP> chips from other boards to 01700.
Not sure if vice versa is valid also.

<CHIP>CD3217</CHIP> chip has firmware, like <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>/8, or <CHIP>TPS65982</CHIP>/8 too.
Code termination identifies the firmware usually.
But you can expect any weird issues from Apple.

Power cycling may be caused by a probelm with a secondary power supply from MLB.
Is the machine recognized in DFU?
Do you get stable <SIGNAL>PPBUS_AON</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>3V8_AON</SIGNAL>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01949</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with bad <CHIP>CD3217</CHIP>
threads.message: Ok I've taken the CD3217B12 from the M1 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02020</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> and it has resolved the issue. I'll add that to logi.wiki or repair.wiki

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01949</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with bad <CHIP>CD3217</CHIP>
threads.message:
Tanks for confirmation.
We need trusted references like this, to be sure in the repair processes.
